value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The readers faculty is a queer one. He has the power to</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">make houses and countries visible, men and women and their</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">thoughts and emotions, from marks on a printed page.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He is not a scholar and so lacks many props, many</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">special tastes that control <add hand="ms" place="above">[anticipate?]</add>, and direct.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He has a sensibility that millions of perfectly</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">literate people, who 'read' the paper, are without.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">And in the play, when the body of the actor is visible,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">xmxmxmxmxmxx with all its implications,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">some of the elements that the reader is able to extract</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">from the 
            <choice>
              <sic>pirnted</sic>
              <corr>printed</corr>
            </choice> page are absent. We do not 'know'</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>Marloew</sic>
              <corr>Marlowe</corr>
            </choice>, <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-tdek" key="Dekker, Thomas">Dekker</rs>, <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-ctou" key="Tourneur, Cecil">Tourneur</rs> <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-jfor" key="Ford, John">Ford</rs>, as we know</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Sir <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-tbro" key="Browne, Thomas">Thomas Browne</rs> or <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-rbur" key="Burton, Robert">Burton</rs>.What we have of them is what it</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">was possible for the actors <add hand="ms" place="inline">t</add>o say. And as 
            <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-wsha" key="Shakespeare, William"><choice>
              <sic>Shakenspere</sic> <!-- Shakenspeare, not Stirredpeare -->
              <corr>Shakespeare</corr>
            </choice></rs></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">could say everything finally, more at least than has been</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">said before and 
            <choice>
              <sic>sincem</sic>
              <corr>since</corr>
            </choice> through the mouths of his characters,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">he is at once the best 
            <choice>
              <sic>kniwn</sic>
              <corr>known</corr>
            </choice> and the 
            <choice>
              <sic>l ast</sic>
              <corr>least</corr>
            </choice> known of all</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">writers. At the same time we have the most completely</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">articulate of men and nobody in 
            <choice>
              <sic>particualr</sic>
              <corr>particular</corr>
            </choice>.</l>

<add xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" place="margin">
            <l>When we turn</l>
            <l>to <choice>
              <sic>S.</sic>
              <corr>Shakespeare</corr>
            </choice><del>we</del></l>
            <l><del>come to the</del> first</l>
            <l>their [illeg.]</l>
            <l>are compounded.</l>
          </add>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">For this reason he is the most read of all writers.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">And 
            <choice>
              <sic>very</sic>
              <corr>every</corr>
            </choice> reader has a dozen different methods of 
            <choice>
              <sic>catvhing</sic>
              <corr>catching</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">him. He is the most read of all writers because</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">no one has ever 
            <choice>
              <sic>ummed</sic>
              <corr>summed</corr>
            </choice> him up. There is 
            <choice>
              <sic>soething</sic>
              <corr>something</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">still to be discovered. He has given tongue to so much</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">that every one can find 
            <choice>
              <sic>himse f</sic>
              <corr>himself</corr>
            </choice> in Shakespeare. The 
            <choice>
              <sic>auto</sic>
              <corr>autobiographical</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>biopgrahical</sic>
              <corr>autobiographical</corr>
            </choice> element in 
            <choice>
              <sic>Shakeapearn</sic>
              <corr>Shakespearean</corr>
            </choice> criticism is a proof</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of of this. Each of the 
            <choice>
              <sic>exploerers</sic>
              <corr>explorers</corr>
            </choice> seems for a moment</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to sum up; and then is consumed and the 
            <choice>
              <sic>unreorded</sic>
              <corr>unrecorded</corr>
            </choice> light</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">streams round him. That is one reason for his 
            <choice>
              <sic>perptaul</sic>
              <corr>perpetual</corr>
            </choice></l>
